background_dashed.customLabel: In Pre-school (<6 years old) participants, there is a moderate-to-strong effect in favor of SENS on Overall ASD symptoms. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 12 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In School-age (6-12 years old) participants, there is a moderate-to-strong effect in favor of SENS on Overall ASD symptoms. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 3 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In Pre-school (<6 years old) participants, there is a very strong effect in favor of SENS on Sensory Profile. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 4 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In Pre-school (<6 years old) participants, there is a small-to-moderate effect in favor of SENS on Social-communication. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 2 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In School-age (6-12 years old) participants, there is a very strong effect in favor of SENS on Adaptive behaviors. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 2 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In Pre-school (<6 years old) participants, there is a moderate-to-strong effect in favor of SENS on Global cognition (IQ). Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 2 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In Pre-school (<6 years old) participants, there is a small-to-moderate effect in favor of SENS on Language (Overall skills). Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 2 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.
